content: quote: Originally posted by TheBerk: Oh ya because the decisions they made over the last 10 years were right on. And the Gvernment had no input or interference whatsoever, right? http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov/portal/site/nhtsa/menuitem.43a...69eea57529cdba046a0/ Corporate Average Fuel Economy (C A F E ) First enacted by Congress in 1975, the purpose of CAFE is to reduce energy consumption by increasing the fuel economy of cars and light trucks. Regulating CAFE is the responsibility of NHTSA and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). NHTSA sets fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the U.S.; EPA calculates the average fuel economy for each manufacturer. This site contains an immense amount of information about the CAFE program, including a program overview, related rulemaking activities, research, fleet characteristics and summaries of manufacturers’ fuel economy performance since 1978. When the Gov gets involved with telling manufacturers how to do business, it reminds of the saying about a Camel A Camel was a Horse designed by a Committee
quote: Originally posted by TheBerk: Oh ya because the decisions they made over the last 10 years were right on.
reply: And the Gvernment had no input or interference whatsoever, right? http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov/portal/site/nhtsa/menuitem.43a...69eea57529cdba046a0/ Corporate Average Fuel Economy (C A F E ) First enacted by Congress in 1975, the purpose of CAFE is to reduce energy consumption by increasing the fuel economy of cars and light trucks. Regulating CAFE is the responsibility of NHTSA and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). NHTSA sets fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the U.S.; EPA calculates the average fuel economy for each manufacturer. This site contains an immense amount of information about the CAFE program, including a program overview, related rulemaking activities, research, fleet characteristics and summaries of manufacturers’ fuel economy performance since 1978. When the Gov gets involved with telling manufacturers how to do business, it reminds of the saying about a Camel A Camel was a Horse designed by a Committee
title: Federal Auto company

content: It isn't government regulation that has caused Chevy and other American automakers to produce cars such as the Chevy Beat, it's actually common sense. For the past decade, Chevy/GM was ill advised in producing gas guzzlers (see Hummer) which Americans stopped buying for economic and environmental reasons. Instead, Americans were turning into foreign autmoakers to meet their needs (see Prius, Camry, etc.) Now, with our money in their hands, they damn well better start making more economical cars as opposed to a huge line of vehicles in which many Americans can't afford. It's time to go back to basics. Be bitter all you want, but it'll make me sick to know all the Bail out money was going towards producing a 2012 Camaro that I will never be able to afford myself.
reply: It isn't government regulation that has caused Chevy and other American automakers to produce cars such as the Chevy Beat, it's actually common sense. When the Gov gets involved with telling manufacturers how to do business, it reminds of the saying about a Camel A Camel was a Horse designed by a Committee Wow, valid point, but the fact is, those fuel standards are even high for today. Besides, putting standards on feul economy of vehicles didn't handcuff these manufacterers. In fact, manufactors are reintroducing their "muscle" cars as more safe and environmentally friendly then that bad boys of the 60s and 70s. Consumers help dictate the market, they found what they wanted in Toyota, Hyundai, etc. I for one will never buy anything but American, but I can understand why over the last decade people have shifted gears.
quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: quote: Originally posted by TheBerk: Oh ya because the decisions they made over the last 10 years were right on. And the Gvernment had no input or interference whatsoever, right? http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov/portal/site/nhtsa/menuitem.43a...69eea57529cdba046a0/ Corporate Average Fuel Economy (C A F E ) First enacted by Congress in 1975, the purpose of CAFE is to reduce energy consumption by increasing the fuel economy of cars and light trucks. Regulating CAFE is the responsibility of NHTSA and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). NHTSA sets fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the U.S.; EPA calculates the average fuel economy for each manufacturer. This site contains an immense amount of information about the CAFE program, including a program overview, related rulemaking activities, research, fleet characteristics and summaries of manufacturers’ fuel economy performance since 1978. When the Gov gets involved with telling manufacturers how to do business, it reminds of the saying about a Camel A Camel was a Horse designed by a Committee

In fact, manufactors are reintroducing their "muscle" cars as more safe and environmentally friendly then that bad boys of the 60s and 70s. Consumers help dictate the market, they found what they wanted in Toyota, Hyundai, etc. I for one will never buy anything but American, but I can understand why over the last decade people have shifted gears.
title: Federal Auto company

content: quote: Originally posted by EAG154: quote: Originally posted by TheBerk: It isn't government regulation that has caused Chevy and other American automakers to produce cars such as the Chevy Beat, it's actually common sense. For the past decade, Chevy/GM was ill advised in producing gas guzzlers (see Hummer) which Americans stopped buying for economic and environmental reasons. Instead, Americans were turning into foreign autmoakers to meet their needs (see Prius, Camry, etc.) Now, with our money in their hands, they damn well better start making more economical cars as opposed to a huge line of vehicles in which many Americans can't afford. It's time to go back to basics. Be bitter all you want, but it'll make me sick to know all the Bail out money was going towards producing a 2012 Camaro that I will never be able to afford myself. non-sense, the biggest sellers have been the big SUV'S, American auto buyers have always favored big cars that have big engines and don't much give a sht how much gas costs or how much gas their monsters guzzle! Your argument makes no sense. Really, enlighten me! "www.forbes.com/2008/12/03/2008-car-sales-forbeslife-cx_jm_1203cars.html"
